elements.content: The slow diffusion reaction of octacyanometalate [W­(CN)8]3–, lanthanide ions, and 4,4′-bipyridyl-N,N′-dioxide (bpdo) has generated a series of isostructural three-dimensional pillared-layer networks with general formula [Ln­(bpdo)1.5(H2O)­W­(CN)8]­·0.5CH3OH­·6H2O (Ln = Dy–Yb, Gd), in which Ln­(III) atoms adopted an unusual seven-coordinated geometry in the cyanometalate-based lanthanide system. This building approach on the basis of the simultaneous employment of cyanide and bpdo bridges offers potential possibilities for designing and constructing 5d-4f coordination networks with high dimensionalities. Interestingly, the LnIII-bpdo-WV(CN)8 system has undergone an unique two-step phase transition upon prolonging the diffusion reaction time, together with the structural changing from initial ion pair through two-dimensional layer to final three-dimensional pillared-layer network. Magnetic studies of all compounds revealed typical and dominant single-ion magnetic behaviors over the weak coupling interactions between spin centers.

This building approach on the basis of the simultaneous employment of cyanide and bpdo bridges offers potential possibilities for designing and constructing 5d-4f coordination networks with high dimensionalities. Interestingly, the LnIII-bpdo-WV(CN)8 system has undergone an unique two-step phase transition upon prolonging the diffusion reaction time, together with the structural changing from initial ion pair through two-dimensional layer to final three-dimensional pillared-layer network. Magnetic studies of all compounds revealed typical and dominant single-ion magnetic behaviors over the weak coupling interactions between spin centers.

elements.content: A series of isostructural three-dimensional (3D) pillared-layer compounds were synthesized through the diffusion reaction of [WV(CN)8]3−, lanthanide ions, and 4,4′-bipyridyl-N,N′-dioxide (bpdo), where Ln­(III) atoms adopted an unusual seven-coordinated geometry. Notably, the LnIII-bpdo-WV(CN)8 system underwent an unique two-step phase transition together with structural changes from ion pair through two-dimensional layer to 3D pillared-layer network. Magnetic studies revealed dominant single-ion magnetic behaviors.

Notably, the LnIII-bpdo-WV(CN)8 system underwent an unique two-step phase transition together with structural changes from ion pair through two-dimensional layer to 3D pillared-layer network. Magnetic studies revealed dominant single-ion magnetic behaviors.

elements.content: The study of cyanide-bridged molecule-based magnetic materials has become a hot topic in recent years. Of all the known cyanometalate precursors, octacyanometalates [M­(CN)8]3– (M = Mo, W) are a versatile class of building blocks adopting variable spatial configurations depending on the coordination environment. Thus, inorganic–organic [M­(CN)8]3–-based molecular materials have received increasing interest owing to their fascinating architectures and promising applications. In this kind of coordination compound, metal atoms offer spin and orbital angular magnetic momentum, and cyano species afford magnetic coupling, and organic ligands can supply the structural flexibilities. It is well know that the lanthanide ions usually exhibit an intrinsic nature due to their considerable single ion anisotropy, high spin numbers, and flexible coordination geometries. Therefore, the combination of various cyanometalate building units, lanthanide ions, and organic ligands provides great challenges and opportunities, taking account of adjusting the intriguing topologies and specific functionalities.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The study of cyanide-bridged molecule-based magnetic materials has become a hot topic in recent years. Of all the known cyanometalate precursors, octacyanometalates [M(CN)8]3- (M = Mo, W) are a versatile class of building blocks adopting variable spatial configurations depending on the coordination environment. Thus, inorganic-organic [M(CN)8]3--based molecular materials have received increasing interest owing to their fascinating architectures and promising applications. In this kind of coordination compound, metal atoms offer spin and orbital angular magnetic momentum, and cyano species afford magnetic coupling, and organic ligands can supply the structural flexibilities. It is well know that the lanthanide ions usually exhibit an intrinsic nature due to their considerable single ion anisotropy, high spin numbers, and flexible coordination geometries. Therefore, the combination of various cyanometalate building units, lanthanide ions, and organic ligands provides great challenges and opportunities, taking account of adjusting the intriguing topologies and specific functionalities.

elements.content: In an effort to control topological structures of high-dimensional compounds involving lanthanide ions and [M­(CN)8]3–, the rationally selected aromatic single-ring or heterocyclic-ring bidentate ligands are able to connect magnetic centers isolating intriguing functionalities in the resulting bimetallic materials. In particular, the bridging bidentate ligands such as 1,2-di­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene, 4,4′-bipyridine, 4,4′-dipyriyl disulfide, and 4,4′-bipyridine-N,N′-dioxide, have been successfully applied by Sieklucka et al. in the fabrication of high-dimensional compounds from preorganic pentadecanuclear clusters M9W6 (M = Mn, Co). Apart from these examples, an appealing case is represented by the Mn2Nb assembly, which was built of local {Mn2-(4,4′-bipyridine-N,N′-dioxide)} moieties integrated into an extended cyanide-based framework showing long-range ferromagnetic ordering.

In particular, the bridging bidentate ligands such as 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene, 4,4'-bipyridine, 4,4'-dipyriyl disulfide, and 4,4'-bipyridine-N,N'-dioxide, have been successfully applied by Sieklucka et al. in the fabrication of high-dimensional compounds from preorganic pentadecanuclear clusters M9W6 (M = Mn, Co). Apart from these examples, an appealing case is represented by the Mn2Nb assembly, which was built of local {Mn2-(4,4'-bipyridine-N,N'-dioxide)} moieties integrated into an extended cyanide-based framework showing long-range ferromagnetic ordering.

elements.content: In our earlier work, the combination of neutral two-dimensional (2D) layers [Ln­(H2O)5­W­(CN)8] and pyrazine afforded isostructural networks [Ln­(H2O)4­(pyrazine)0.5W­(CN)8] (Ln = La–Tb). The linear exobidentate pyrazine acted as the pillars between layers generating an open structure. The magnetic properties were obviously tuned by the type of lanthanide ions because of ligand field effects and exchange interactions. In spite of the progress made in such complex system, collecting much more experimental data of 5d-4f magnetochemistry to get a more clear view of their magnetic interactions will still be worth doing. In our ongoing research devoted to preparing cyanide-bridged lanthanide compounds with high dimensionalities, herein we applied the paramagnetic [W­(CN)8]3– building unit and a bidentate 4,4′-bipyridyl-N,N′-dioxide (bpdo) as a coligand to react with lanthanide ions, isolating the isostructural cyano-bpdo mixed-bridged family with general formula [Ln­(bpdo)1.5(H2O)­W­(CN)8]­·0.5CH3OH­·6H2O (Ln = Dy­(1), Ho­(2), Er­(3), Tm­(4), Yb­(5), Gd­(6)) with a three-dimensional (3D) pillared-layer structure. The bridging bpdo was utilized here because this type of planar organic ligand can bond with adjacent metal ions by two equivalent oxygen atoms, and then probably increase the dimensionalities of the networks. Interestingly, such a Ln­(III)-bpdo-W­(V) system has undergone a remarkable time-of-diffusion-induced two-step structural switching process from initial ion pair [Dy­(bpdo)4(H2O)4]­[W­(CN)8] (1a) through intermediate 2D layer {Dy­(bpdo)2.5(CH3OH)­(H2O)2­[W­(CN)8]0.5}­·[W­(CN)8]0.5­·CH3OH­·H2O (1b) to final 3D pillared-layer 1 from one-pot crystallization. To the best of our knowledge, the consecutive two-step structural conversion phenomenon has not been documented in the cyanide systems derived from octacyanometalates, although different types of phase transformations were reported previously. It is also worth noting that the lanthanide centers in compounds 1a and 1b adopted an eight-coordinated square-antiprismatic geometry relative to the seven-coordinated pentagonal bipyramid found in compounds 1. Seven-coordinated lanthanide ions are rarely observed so far in the cyanide system. The magnetic behaviors of all compounds were also studied.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used as obtained. The precursor [HN­(n-C4H9)3]3­W­(CN)8 was synthesized according to the reported method. Infrared spectra (IR) were measured in the 4000–400 cm–1 range with a Nicolet FT 1703X spectrometer (KBr pellets). The elemental analyses of metals were carried out on energy-dispersive spectrometry (EDS, Oxford). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected with a Cu-Kα source on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer. Magnetic measurements were performed on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMP-XL7 magnetometer, and the diamagnetic contributions of all constituent atoms were subtracted by the use of Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used as obtained. The precursor [HN(n-C4H9)3]3W(CN)8 was synthesized according to the reported method. Infrared spectra (IR) were measured in the 4000-400 cm-1 range with a Nicolet FT 1703X spectrometer (KBr pellets). The elemental analyses of metals were carried out on energy-dispersive spectrometry (EDS, Oxford). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected with a Cu-Kα source on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer. Magnetic measurements were performed on a Quantum Design SQUID MPMP-XL7 magnetometer, and the diamagnetic contributions of all constituent atoms were subtracted by the use of Pascal's constants.

elements.content: A small glass vial (3 mL) containing Ln­(NO3)·6H2O (Ln = Dy–Yb, Gd) (0.05 mmol) and 4,4′-bipyridine-N,N′-dioxide (0.75 mmol) was placed into a big glass vial (15 mL) containing [HN­(n-C4H9)3]3­[W­(CN)8]­·4H2O (0.05 mmol) at room temperature. The small vial was filled with distilled water, while the big via was filled with methanol. Then the big vial was sealed. After allowing the solution to stand for one month in the dark, red block crystals [Ln­(bpdo)1.5(H2O)­W­(CN)8]­·0.5CH3OH­·6H2O (Ln = Dy­(1), Ho­(2), Er­(3), Tm­(4), Yb­(5), Gd­(6)) were formed in the small vials. Interestingly, a time-of-diffusion-induced resolvation–recrystallization transformation was obviously observed during the crystal growth process in such LnIII-bpdo-WV(CN)8 system (Ln = Dy–Yb). Here we take the phase transition process of DyW compounds for an example. In detail, colorless block crystals of [Dy­(bpdo)4­(H2O)4]­[W­(CN)8] (1a) were formed in the small vial when the solution was placed for 3 days. After further 1 week, red block crystals of {Dy­(bpdo)2.5­(CH3OH)­(H2O)2[W­(CN)8]0.5}­·[W­(CN)8]0.5·CH3OH·H2O (1b) appeared, and then red block crystals of [Dy­(bpdo)1.5(H2O)­W­(CN)8]­·0.5CH3OH­·6H2O (1) were generated after another 3 weeks. All crystal samples exhibited high stabilities in the air upon removal from the mother liquid, and PXRD analysis clearly indicated the high purities of these polycrystalline samples (Figure S1). Atomic ratios (EDS results) of W/Ln for 1a, 1b, 1–6 were approximately equal to 1. For 1a: W/Dy = 1.08/1.00; for 1b: W/Dy = 0.94/1.00; for 1: W/Dy = 0.96/1.00; for 2: W/Ho = 1.06/1.00; for 3: W/Er = 1.07/1.00; for 4: W/Tm = 0.90/1.00; for 5: W/Yb = 0.99/1.00; for 6: W/Gd = 1.09/1.00. IR spectra for 1a: νC≡N = 2032, cm–1, 2082 cm–1, 2135 cm–1; for 1b: νC≡N = 2100 cm–1, 2122 cm–1; for 1: νC≡N = 2095 cm–1, 2121 cm–1; for 2: νC≡N = 2100 cm–1, 2121 cm–1; for 3: νC≡N = 2095 cm–1, 2121 cm–1; for 4: νC≡N = 2099 cm–1, 2120 cm–1; for 5: νC≡N = 2099 cm–1, 2122 cm–1; for 6: νC≡N = 2100 cm–1, 2123 cm–1.

Syntheses

A small glass vial (3 mL) containing Ln(NO3)⋅6H2O (Ln = Dy-Yb, Gd) (0.05 mmol) and 4,4'-bipyridine-N,N'-dioxide (0.75 mmol) was placed into a big glass vial (15 mL) containing [HN(n-C4H9)3]3[W(CN)8]⋅4H2O (0.05 mmol) at room temperature. The small vial was filled with distilled water, while the big via was filled with methanol. Then the big vial was sealed. After allowing the solution to stand for one month in the dark, red block crystals [Ln(bpdo)1.5(H2O)W(CN)8]⋅0.5CH3OH⋅6H2O (Ln = Dy(1), Ho(2), Er(3), Tm(4), Yb(5), Gd(6)) were formed in the small vials. Interestingly, a time-of-diffusion-induced resolvation-recrystallization transformation was obviously observed during the crystal growth process in such LnIII-bpdo-WV(CN)8 system (Ln = Dy-Yb). Here we take the phase transition process of DyW compounds for an example. In detail, colorless block crystals of [Dy(bpdo)4(H2O)4][W(CN)8] (1a) were formed in the small vial when the solution was placed for 3 days. After further 1 week, red block crystals of {Dy(bpdo)2.5(CH3OH)(H2O)2[W(CN)8]0.5}⋅[W(CN)8]0.5⋅CH3OH⋅H2O (1b) appeared, and then red block crystals of [Dy(bpdo)1.5(H2O)W(CN)8]⋅0.5CH3OH⋅6H2O (1) were generated after another 3 weeks. All crystal samples exhibited high stabilities in the air upon removal from the mother liquid, and PXRD analysis clearly indicated the high purities of these polycrystalline samples (Figure S1). Atomic ratios (EDS results) of W/Ln for 1a, 1b, 1-6 were approximately equal to 1. For 1a: W/Dy = 1.08/1.00; for 1b: W/Dy = 0.94/1.00; for 1: W/Dy = 0.96/1.00; for 2: W/Ho = 1.06/1.00; for 3: W/Er = 1.07/1.00; for 4: W/Tm = 0.90/1.00; for 5: W/Yb = 0.99/1.00; for 6: W/Gd = 1.09/1.00. IR spectra for 1a: νC≡N = 2032, cm-1, 2082 cm-1, 2135 cm-1; for 1b: νC≡N = 2100 cm-1, 2122 cm-1; for 1: νC≡N = 2095 cm-1, 2121 cm-1; for 2: νC≡N = 2100 cm-1, 2121 cm-1; for 3: νC≡N = 2095 cm-1, 2121 cm-1; for 4: νC≡N = 2099 cm-1, 2120 cm-1; for 5: νC≡N = 2099 cm-1, 2122 cm-1; for 6: νC≡N = 2100 cm-1, 2123 cm-1.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction patterns of all compounds were collected using a Bruker Apex II diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator and Mo-Kα radiation. All structures were solved using the Patterson method with SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F 2 using SHELXL-2014. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms joined to bpdo ligands and methanol molecules were calculated for the idealized geometry, and a riding model of the refinement was applied. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were found from the difference Fourier map, and then refined using a riding model. CCDC reference numbers are as follows: 1570379 (1a), 1570380 (1b), 1570384 (1), 1570381 (2), 1570385 (3), 1570382 (4), 1570383 (5), and 1570386 (6). Crystallographic data and refine parameters for all compounds are listed in , and selected bond distances and bond angles are presented in Tables S1–S4.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Analysis

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction patterns of all compounds were collected using a Bruker Apex II diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator and Mo-Kα radiation. All structures were solved using the Patterson method with SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F 2 using SHELXL-2014. All of the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms joined to bpdo ligands and methanol molecules were calculated for the idealized geometry, and a riding model of the refinement was applied. Hydrogen atoms of water molecules were found from the difference Fourier map, and then refined using a riding model. CCDC reference numbers are as follows: 1570379 (1a), 1570380 (1b), 1570384 (1), 1570381 (2), 1570385 (3), 1570382 (4), 1570383 (5), and 1570386 (6). Crystallographic data and refine parameters for all compounds are listed in , and selected bond distances and bond angles are presented in Tables S1-S4.

The generation of diffusion-time dependent products in the LnIII-bpdo-WV(CN)8 system can be roughly explained in terms of the initial reactants, the concentration gradients, and stoichiometries. Here we take the DyW system as an example. At the beginning, the concentration of [W­(CN)8]3– precursors which dissolve and diffuse from big vial to small vial was very low. At this time, the self-assembly between Dy3+ ions, bpdo, and [W­(CN)8]3– precursors produced an ion-pair compound 1a, where the [W­(CN)8]3– units were isolated, and all cyanide groups did not participate in the bonding with Dy­(III) centers. With further diffusion of the [W­(CN)8] component, the concentration gradient of solution in the small vial changed, and part of the cyanide groups in the W­(CN)8 units were involved in the coordination process to Dy­(III) atoms, accompanied by the structural change from initial ion pair (1a) to 2D layer (1b). Single crystals of both compounds exhibited similar block shapes and sizes, so it is difficult to observe this transformation phenomenon by the crystal configuration. Fortunately, the color change of crystals can be significantly observed from colorless to red during the transformation process. We also note with the optical microscope that the amount of crystals 1a gradually decreased when crystals 1b appeared. Then the DyIII/bpdo stoichiometric ratio decreased with the further diffusion of [W­(CN)8]3– precursors into the small vial, leading to a 3D pillared-layer network (1), in which more cyanide groups of [W­(CN)8]3– bridged to Dy­(III) atoms. At the end, crystals of 1b transformed exclusively to 1, indicating that compound 1 was the most thermodynamically favored product in such LnIII-bpdo-WV(CN)8 system. It did not work for observing the transformation process from 1b to 1 only by the color change because these block crystals of both compounds are red. Indeed, this phase transition is related to a resolvation–recrystallization process viewed from the molecular level, accompanied by the rearrangement of the coordination sphere around metal centers, as discussed in the following structural descriptions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Growth Process

The generation of diffusion-time dependent products in the LnIII-bpdo-WV(CN)8 system can be roughly explained in terms of the initial reactants, the concentration gradients, and stoichiometries. Here we take the DyW system as an example. At the beginning, the concentration of [W(CN)8]3- precursors which dissolve and diffuse from big vial to small vial was very low. At this time, the self-assembly between Dy3+ ions, bpdo, and [W(CN)8]3- precursors produced an ion-pair compound 1a, where the [W(CN)8]3- units were isolated, and all cyanide groups did not participate in the bonding with Dy(III) centers. With further diffusion of the [W(CN)8] component, the concentration gradient of solution in the small vial changed, and part of the cyanide groups in the W(CN)8 units were involved in the coordination process to Dy(III) atoms, accompanied by the structural change from initial ion pair (1a) to 2D layer (1b). Single crystals of both compounds exhibited similar block shapes and sizes, so it is difficult to observe this transformation phenomenon by the crystal configuration. Fortunately, the color change of crystals can be significantly observed from colorless to red during the transformation process. We also note with the optical microscope that the amount of crystals 1a gradually decreased when crystals 1b appeared. Then the DyIII/bpdo stoichiometric ratio decreased with the further diffusion of [W(CN)8]3- precursors into the small vial, leading to a 3D pillared-layer network (1), in which more cyanide groups of [W(CN)8]3- bridged to Dy(III) atoms. At the end, crystals of 1b transformed exclusively to 1, indicating that compound 1 was the most thermodynamically favored product in such LnIII-bpdo-WV(CN)8 system. It did not work for observing the transformation process from 1b to 1 only by the color change because these block crystals of both compounds are red. Indeed, this phase transition is related to a resolvation-recrystallization process viewed from the molecular level, accompanied by the rearrangement of the coordination sphere around metal centers, as discussed in the following structural descriptions.

elements.content:
X-ray structural analysis revealed that ion-pair compound 1a crystallizes in the tetragonal space group P4/n. The structure consists of cationic [Dy­(bpdo)4­(H2O)4]3+ and anionic [W­(CN)8]3– (a).

The Dy and W centers are located on a special position with 4̅ symmetry, and a 2-fold rotation axis, respectively. The eight-coordinated W atom displays a distorted square antiprismatic geometry, typical for octacyanotunsgate­(V). Eight cyanide ligands are all terminal, and the mean W1–C and C–N bond distances are 2.172 and 1.152 Å, respectively. The W1–CN bond angles are in the range of 175.4–176.1°, exhibiting almost linear structure. The Dy center is eight-coordinated and lies in a slightly distorted square antiprismatic environment with four oxygen atoms from four terminal bpdo as well as four water molecules. The dihedral angle between two pyridyl rings of all bpdo ligands is about 9.7°. The average Dy1–O bond length is approximately 2.371 Å. The coordination environment of Dy is identical to those observed in monometallic Dy-bpdo compounds. Then, the isolated [Dy­(bpdo)4­(H2O)4]3+ and [W­(CN)8]3– moieties are connected by the well-defined hydrogen bonding (b, Table S5) and π–π stacks (the centroid distance between two rings is about 3.909 Å, c) of bpdo ligands, isolating a 3D supramolecular network. The ionic structure of 1a was relatively common in the octacyanometalate-based bimetallic compounds.

Crystal Structures

X-ray structural analysis revealed that ion-pair compound 1a crystallizes in the tetragonal space group P4/n. The structure consists of cationic [Dy(bpdo)4(H2O)4]3+ and anionic [W(CN)8]3- (a).

The Dy and W centers are located on a special position with 4̅ symmetry, and a 2-fold rotation axis, respectively. The eight-coordinated W atom displays a distorted square antiprismatic geometry, typical for octacyanotunsgate(V). Eight cyanide ligands are all terminal, and the mean W1-C and C-N bond distances are 2.172 and 1.152 Å, respectively. The W1-CN bond angles are in the range of 175.4-176.1°, exhibiting almost linear structure. The Dy center is eight-coordinated and lies in a slightly distorted square antiprismatic environment with four oxygen atoms from four terminal bpdo as well as four water molecules. The dihedral angle between two pyridyl rings of all bpdo ligands is about 9.7°. The average Dy1-O bond length is approximately 2.371 Å. The coordination environment of Dy is identical to those observed in monometallic Dy-bpdo compounds. Then, the isolated [Dy(bpdo)4(H2O)4]3+ and [W(CN)8]3- moieties are connected by the well-defined hydrogen bonding (b, Table S5) and π-π stacks (the centroid distance between two rings is about 3.909 Å, c) of bpdo ligands, isolating a 3D supramolecular network. The ionic structure of 1a was relatively common in the octacyanometalate-based bimetallic compounds.

elements.content: Compound 1b has the monoclinic system with a C2/c space group and displays a 2D cationic layer-like structure, and the charge of which is balanced by the [W­(CN)8]3– anion (a). The asymmetric unit is composed of one {Dy­(bpdo)2.5­(CH3OH)­(H2O)2­[W­(CN)8]0.5}1.5+ cation, half an isolated [W­(CN)8]3– ion, as well as the crystallized methanol and water molecules. There are two crystallographically independent W­(V) atoms (W1 and W2) in the structure, which are both described as a square antiprism. Two trans cyanide species in the [W1­(CN)8] unit connect to the neighboring Dy­(III) atoms and the six remaining are terminal, whereas eight cyanide ligands in the isolated [W2­(CN)8] unit are all terminal. The eight-coordinated Dy­(III) atoms take a distorted slightly square antiprismatic {DyNO7} configuration, which is filled by one bridging cyanide group, one terminal bpdo ligand, three bridging bpdo ligands, two water molecules, and one methanol molecule. The Dy1–N and average Dy1–O bond lengths are 2.582 and 2.376 Å, respectively, and the Dy1-NC unit is far from linearity with the angle of 168.0°, in contrast to the almost linear W1–CN bonds.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1b has the monoclinic system with a C2/c space group and displays a 2D cationic layer-like structure, and the charge of which is balanced by the [W(CN)8]3- anion (a). The asymmetric unit is composed of one {Dy(bpdo)2.5(CH3OH)(H2O)2[W(CN)8]0.5}1.5+ cation, half an isolated [W(CN)8]3- ion, as well as the crystallized methanol and water molecules. There are two crystallographically independent W(V) atoms (W1 and W2) in the structure, which are both described as a square antiprism. Two trans cyanide species in the [W1(CN)8] unit connect to the neighboring Dy(III) atoms and the six remaining are terminal, whereas eight cyanide ligands in the isolated [W2(CN)8] unit are all terminal. The eight-coordinated Dy(III) atoms take a distorted slightly square antiprismatic {DyNO7} configuration, which is filled by one bridging cyanide group, one terminal bpdo ligand, three bridging bpdo ligands, two water molecules, and one methanol molecule. The Dy1-N and average Dy1-O bond lengths are 2.582 and 2.376 Å, respectively, and the Dy1-NC unit is far from linearity with the angle of 168.0°, in contrast to the almost linear W1-CN bonds.

elements.content: As a result, the intermetallic connectivities through cyanide bridges and bpdo yield cyano-bpdo mixed bridged cationic {Dy­(bpdo)2.5­(CH3OH)­(H2O)2­[W­(CN)8]0.5}1.5+ grid-like layers in the ab crystallographic plane (b). The dihedral angle of two pyridyl rings from the bridging bpdo ligand along the [0 1 0] direction are 38.0°, in contrast to the coplanar two pyridyl rings of the bpdo ligands along the [1 0 0] direction. The remaining terminal bpdo ligands with a dihedral angle of about 8.0° between the two pyridyl rings stand on both sides of layers and are involved in the extensive network of π–π stacks connecting neighboring layers by the aromatic rings of bpdo. In fact, there are two kinds of grids in the 2D layer. One is composed of four-metallic Dy4 centers linked by bpdo, while the other consists of six-metallic Dy4W2 centers connected by mixed cyanide groups and bpdo. The adjacent layers are separated through well-defined hydrogen bonds (c, Table S6) and π–π stacks (the centroid distance between two rings is about 3.541 Å, d) of bpdo, giving rise to a 3D supramolecular network, in which the isolated [W­(CN)8]3– units and crystallized solvent molecules are trapped.

The dihedral angle of two pyridyl rings from the bridging bpdo ligand along the [0 1 0] direction are 38.0°, in contrast to the coplanar two pyridyl rings of the bpdo ligands along the [1 0 0] direction. The remaining terminal bpdo ligands with a dihedral angle of about 8.0° between the two pyridyl rings stand on both sides of layers and are involved in the extensive network of π-π stacks connecting neighboring layers by the aromatic rings of bpdo. In fact, there are two kinds of grids in the 2D layer. One is composed of four-metallic Dy4 centers linked by bpdo, while the other consists of six-metallic Dy4W2 centers connected by mixed cyanide groups and bpdo. The adjacent layers are separated through well-defined hydrogen bonds (c, Table S6) and π-π stacks (the centroid distance between two rings is about 3.541 Å, d) of bpdo, giving rise to a 3D supramolecular network, in which the isolated [W(CN)8]3- units and crystallized solvent molecules are trapped.

elements.content: Compounds 1–6 are isostructural, crystallizing in the monoclinic space group C2/c. Only the structural description of compound 1 is shown here. The structure contains one cationic [Dy­(bpdo)1.5(H2O)]3+, one anionic [W­(CN)8]3–, as well as uncoordinated methanol and water molecules (a). The [W­(CN)8]3– moiety adopts a square antiprismatic geometry, where three cyanide groups bridge to Dy­(III) atoms and the five remaining are terminal. Different to compounds 1a and 1b, interestingly, the Dy­(III) atom in compound 1 is seven-coordinated, which is bound by three oxygen atoms from three bridging bpdo, three cyanide-nitrogen atoms, and one water molecule, yielding a pentagonal bipyramid with a pentagon defined by O2i, N4, O3, N5iii, and O4, and two axial sites filled with O1 and N6ii (symmetry codes: (i) −x + 5/2, y – 1/2, −z + 1/2; (ii) −x + 5/2, y – 1/2, −z + 3/2; (iii) x, −y + 1, z – 1/2). The Dy1–N and Dy1–O lengths fall in the range of 2.358–2.470 Å and 2.274–2.358 Å, respectively. All Dy1–NC units are significantly bent with angles of 153.3–167.8°. The coordination number is relatively small considering the capability of Ln­(III) ions. The seven-coordinated geometrical data of Dy­(III) are identical to those found in monometallic Ln­(III)-bpdo (Ln = Ho, Yb) compounds. Notably, seven-coordinated lanthanide ions are rarely recognized in the cyanide-based lanthanide system.

elements.content: As shown in b–d, two types of bpdo ligands participate in the construction of the 3D structure of compound 1. Within the layer in the bc plane, Dy­(III) centers are connected to W­(V) atoms by three cyanide groups, and simultaneously Dy­(III) atoms are bridged through bpdo, affording a 2D bimetallic layer. Then adjacent 2D layers are further pillared by the other type of bpdo through the -Dy-bpdo-Dy- linkages along the [1 0 0] direction, generating a 3D cyano-bpdo mixed bridged network (d). The dihedral angles of two pyridyl rings of bridging bpdo along the [1 0 0] and [0 1 1̅] directions are 0° and 29.6°, respectively. The 3D structure of compound 1 is comparable to those tetra- hexa-, and octacyanometalate-based bimetallic frameworks with pillared-layer-type structure, which comprised inorganic 2D layers pillared by organic spacer ligands.

The dihedral angles of two pyridyl rings of bridging bpdo along the [1 0 0] and [0 1 1̅] directions are 0° and 29.6°, respectively. The 3D structure of compound 1 is comparable to those tetra- hexa-, and octacyanometalate-based bimetallic frameworks with pillared-layer-type structure, which comprised inorganic 2D layers pillared by organic spacer ligands.

elements.content: After careful comparison with the structures of three DyW compounds (1a, 1b, 1), we can find that the coordination modes of bpdo ligands are completely different. All bpdo species in the ion-pair compound 1 are terminal and coordinated to the Dy centers, while there are two kinds of binding modes (terminal and bridged) of bpdo for 2D compound 1b. In contrast to 1a and 1b, two types of bridging bpdo ligands ensure the 3D pillared-layer architecture of compound 1 via the -Dy-NC-W- and -Dy-bpdo-W- linkages. So the coordination modes of bpdo ligands have an obvious influence on the ultimate structures of compounds.
elements.clean_text: After careful comparison with the structures of three DyW compounds (1a, 1b, 1), we can find that the coordination modes of bpdo ligands are completely different. All bpdo species in the ion-pair compound 1 are terminal and coordinated to the Dy centers, while there are two kinds of binding modes (terminal and bridged) of bpdo for 2D compound 1b. In contrast to 1a and 1b, two types of bridging bpdo ligands ensure the 3D pillared-layer architecture of compound 1 via the -Dy-NC-W- and -Dy-bpdo-W- linkages. So the coordination modes of bpdo ligands have an obvious influence on the ultimate structures of compounds.

elements.content: The magnetic susceptibilities of all compounds were measured at 100 Oe (). The magnetic properties of compounds 1a and 1b were analyzed first here. The experimental χM T value at 300 K for the ion-pair compound 1a is 14.97 cm3 K mol–1 (), which is consistent with the expected one (14.54 cm3 K mol–1) for noninteracting Dy3+ (J = 15/2, g = 4/3) and W5+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions. In contrast, the χM T value of 16.97 cm3 K mol–1 for the layered compound 1b at 300 K is higher than the theoretical one. Upon cooling of the species, the χM T products of both Dy­(III)–W­(V) compounds smoothly decrease until about 25 K, and then decrease steeply to reach the minimums at 1.8 K. The continuous decrease of χM T values on lowering the temperatures and the lack of any peak at low temperatures indicate the absence of magnetic ordering behavior in the investigated temperature range for both compounds. Generally speaking, the spin–orbit coupling and thermal depopulation of the Stark sublevels of Ln­(III) result in the decrease of χM T values upon cooling the temperatures. The thermal depopulation of crystal-field levels arises from the splitting of the isolated-ion ground state of lanthanide ions. Considering the large Dy­(III)···W­(V) space distance for the ion-pair compound 1a, the exchange interaction between spin centers should be very weak, and the magnetic thermal behavior is actually dominated by the single ion properties of DyIII ions. In contrast, the magnetic centers Dy­(III) and W­(V) for 2D compound 1b are linked by cyanide groups and bpdo ligands. The rapid decrease of χM T values at low temperatures for compound 1b might be attributed to the synergistic reaction between the antiferromagnetic interactions of Dy­(III) and W­(V) centers and the thermal depopulation of Ln­(III) Stark sublevels. The χ′ component of ac susceptibility for compound 1b increased smoothly upon cooling temperatures, and no signal appeared from the χ″ component, confirming the absence of any long-range magnetic ordering.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The magnetic susceptibilities of all compounds were measured at 100 Oe (). The magnetic properties of compounds 1a and 1b were analyzed first here. The experimental χM T value at 300 K for the ion-pair compound 1a is 14.97 cm3 K mol-1 (), which is consistent with the expected one (14.54 cm3 K mol-1) for noninteracting Dy3+ (J = 15/2, g = 4/3) and W5+ (S = 1/2, g = 2) ions. In contrast, the χM T value of 16.97 cm3 K mol-1 for the layered compound 1b at 300 K is higher than the theoretical one. Upon cooling of the species, the χM T products of both Dy(III)-W(V) compounds smoothly decrease until about 25 K, and then decrease steeply to reach the minimums at 1.8 K. The continuous decrease of χM T values on lowering the temperatures and the lack of any peak at low temperatures indicate the absence of magnetic ordering behavior in the investigated temperature range for both compounds. Generally speaking, the spin-orbit coupling and thermal depopulation of the Stark sublevels of Ln(III) result in the decrease of χM T values upon cooling the temperatures. The thermal depopulation of crystal-field levels arises from the splitting of the isolated-ion ground state of lanthanide ions. Considering the large Dy(III)⋅⋅⋅W(V) space distance for the ion-pair compound 1a, the exchange interaction between spin centers should be very weak, and the magnetic thermal behavior is actually dominated by the single ion properties of DyIII ions. In contrast, the magnetic centers Dy(III) and W(V) for 2D compound 1b are linked by cyanide groups and bpdo ligands. The rapid decrease of χM T values at low temperatures for compound 1b might be attributed to the synergistic reaction between the antiferromagnetic interactions of Dy(III) and W(V) centers and the thermal depopulation of Ln(III) Stark sublevels. The χ' component of ac susceptibility for compound 1b increased smoothly upon cooling temperatures, and no signal appeared from the χ" component, confirming the absence of any long-range magnetic ordering.

The field-dependent magnetizations of both compounds were measured at 1.8 K to evaluate the intrinsic exchange couplings. With increasing the field, the magnetization increases sharply at low fields and subsequently increase generally to reach the maximum values at 70 kOe without clear saturation. The maximum (9.52 NμB) at 70 kOe for compound 1a is close to the anticipated value of 9 NμB (10 NμB per DyIII ion and 1.0 NμB per WV ion) for antiferromagnetic coupling, whereas the value of 7.05 NμB for compound 1b is much lower than the expected one. The lack of saturation together with the M–H curve obtained at 1.8 K suggests the presence of the large magneto-anisotropy and a low lying excited state in this system. Taking above analysis into account, we can preliminarily draw a conclusion that compounds 1a and 1b exhibited the similar single-ion magnetic behaviors, although both states have different and definite topologies.

With increasing the field, the magnetization increases sharply at low fields and subsequently increase generally to reach the maximum values at 70 kOe without clear saturation. The maximum (9.52 NμB) at 70 kOe for compound 1a is close to the anticipated value of 9 NμB (10 NμB per DyIII ion and 1.0 NμB per WV ion) for antiferromagnetic coupling, whereas the value of 7.05 NμB for compound 1b is much lower than the expected one. The lack of saturation together with the M-H curve obtained at 1.8 K suggests the presence of the large magneto-anisotropy and a low lying excited state in this system. Taking above analysis into account, we can preliminarily draw a conclusion that compounds 1a and 1b exhibited the similar single-ion magnetic behaviors, although both states have different and definite topologies.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of five 3D materials 1–5 were discussed together because of their isomorphosity. The χM T vs T curves of these compounds were found to exhibit the same trend at 300–1.8 K. As shown in , the χM T values at 300 K of 1–5 are higher than the theoretical ones. As the temperature decreases, the χM T values of these series of compounds mainly exhibit the decrease feature until reaching the minimum values at 1.8 K. These magnetic behaviors are typical of properties shown by these 3d-4f systems, where the spin–orbit coupling, thermal depopulation of the Stark sublevels as well as exchange interactions might be presented together. For compounds 1–5, the magnetic properties originate probably from the thermal depopulation of Ln­(III) Stark sublevels and weak antiferromagnetic couplings between Ln­(III) and W­(V) ions. In general, the magnetic interactions containing lanthanide centers are extremely weak and cannot simply be determined from variable-temperature susceptibility because of strong spin–orbit couplings. In contrast to compounds 1a and 1b, the nature of magnetic coupling between Ln3+ and W5+ centers for compounds 1–5 cannot directly be deduced from the decrease of χM T, because of the thermal depopulation of the low-lying excited states of Ln3+ as well as the magnetic coupling between Ln3+ and W5+ ions. No peaks were found in the χ′ and χ″ components of ac susceptibility for these 3D compounds, indicating the absence of any long-range magnetic ordering.

The χM T vs T curves of these compounds were found to exhibit the same trend at 300-1.8 K. As shown in , the χM T values at 300 K of 1-5 are higher than the theoretical ones. As the temperature decreases, the χM T values of these series of compounds mainly exhibit the decrease feature until reaching the minimum values at 1.8 K. These magnetic behaviors are typical of properties shown by these 3d-4f systems, where the spin-orbit coupling, thermal depopulation of the Stark sublevels as well as exchange interactions might be presented together. For compounds 1-5, the magnetic properties originate probably from the thermal depopulation of Ln(III) Stark sublevels and weak antiferromagnetic couplings between Ln(III) and W(V) ions. In general, the magnetic interactions containing lanthanide centers are extremely weak and cannot simply be determined from variable-temperature susceptibility because of strong spin-orbit couplings. In contrast to compounds 1a and 1b, the nature of magnetic coupling between Ln3+ and W5+ centers for compounds 1-5 cannot directly be deduced from the decrease of χM T, because of the thermal depopulation of the low-lying excited states of Ln3+ as well as the magnetic coupling between Ln3+ and W5+ ions. No peaks were found in the χ' and χ" components of ac susceptibility for these 3D compounds, indicating the absence of any long-range magnetic ordering.

elements.content: As far as we know, no available expression can be employed to reasonably fit the magnetic susceptibilities of our cases (1–5). Nevertheless, the isostructural compound GdW (6) without single ion anisotropy could provide us some information for understanding the magnetic nature of these compounds. Compound 6 was prepared according to the same synthesis method of compounds 1–5 except using Gd­(NO3)3·6H2O as the precursor. The PXRD and magnetic nature of 6 were characterized (Figures S2 and S3). The χM T value of 10.02 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K is higher than the anticipated one (8.25 cm3 K mol–1) for free Gd­(III) ion (S = 7/2 with ground state 8 S 7/2) and W­(V) ion (S = 1/2) with g = 2.00. The χM T value slightly decreases upon cooling temperatures and eventually reaches the minimum of 8.76 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K, confirming the very weak intramolecular magnetic coupling between Gd­(III) and W­(V) centers. A fitting of the data to Curie–Weiss law yields θ = −0.86 K. The small and negative θ value indicates weak antiferromagnetic interactions between Gd­(III) and W­(V) spin centers. The field dependent magnetization at 1.8 K increases quickly in low fields (0–20 kOe) and increases slowly above this field to the saturation value of 9.49 NμB in 70 kOe. This saturation magnetization is between the anticipated values of Gd­(III)–W­(V) antiferromagnetic and ferromagnetic couplings. No hysteresis loop was observed down to T = 1.8 K.

elements.content: With regard to the magnetic analysis of compound 6, we can speculate that the magnetic coupling in these isotructural compounds 1–5 should be also very weak in comparison to the strong LnIII single-ion effects. They are the same as those lanthanide compounds derived from hexa- or octacyanometalates, in which the coupling constants between spin centers were very small. So, the magnetic properties of 1–5 are actually dominated by the single ion properties of 4f ions. The dc field-dependent magnetizations were measured at 1.8 K to verify the single ion properties. As the applied fields increase, the magnetization values display a steady increase. Similar to two DyW compounds (1a, 1b) and the isostructural compound 6, the magnetization values of 1–5 at 70 kOe were far below the theoretical saturation ones for the antiferromagnetic coupling interaction, revealing the effect induced by single ion magnetic anisotropy and/or the population of low-lying excited states.

They are the same as those lanthanide compounds derived from hexa- or octacyanometalates, in which the coupling constants between spin centers were very small. So, the magnetic properties of 1-5 are actually dominated by the single ion properties of 4f ions. The dc field-dependent magnetizations were measured at 1.8 K to verify the single ion properties. As the applied fields increase, the magnetization values display a steady increase. Similar to two DyW compounds (1a, 1b) and the isostructural compound 6, the magnetization values of 1-5 at 70 kOe were far below the theoretical saturation ones for the antiferromagnetic coupling interaction, revealing the effect induced by single ion magnetic anisotropy and/or the population of low-lying excited states.

elements.content: To summarize, by introducing bpdo as coligand, we have succeeded in constructing a series of isostructural cyano-bpdo mixed-bridged Ln­(III)­W­(V) compounds with a 3D pillared-layer structure. Notably, this Ln­(III)-bpdo-W­(V) system has undergone an interesting two-step structural transition from the initial ion-pair structure through an intermediate 2D layer to a final 3D pillared layer from one-pot crystallization, which is obviously induced by the time of solution diffusion. The flexibility of coordination modes of bpdo ligands may facilitate the assembly of variable topologies. The seven-coordinated Ln­(III) centers are extremely scarce in cyanometalate-based systems with lanthanide ions. Magnetic studies showed that all compounds displayed similar magnetisms due to the dominant single-ion properties of LnIII over the possible weak cyanide-mediated LnIII-WV coupling interactions. Our further work will be devoted to constructing extended materials based on lanthanide ions and [M­(CN)8]3– units with long spacer linkers that might exhibit fascinating 3D magnetic ordering.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

To summarize, by introducing bpdo as coligand, we have succeeded in constructing a series of isostructural cyano-bpdo mixed-bridged Ln(III)W(V) compounds with a 3D pillared-layer structure. Notably, this Ln(III)-bpdo-W(V) system has undergone an interesting two-step structural transition from the initial ion-pair structure through an intermediate 2D layer to a final 3D pillared layer from one-pot crystallization, which is obviously induced by the time of solution diffusion. The flexibility of coordination modes of bpdo ligands may facilitate the assembly of variable topologies. The seven-coordinated Ln(III) centers are extremely scarce in cyanometalate-based systems with lanthanide ions. Magnetic studies showed that all compounds displayed similar magnetisms due to the dominant single-ion properties of LnIII over the possible weak cyanide-mediated LnIII-WV coupling interactions. Our further work will be devoted to constructing extended materials based on lanthanide ions and [M(CN)8]3- units with long spacer linkers that might exhibit fascinating 3D magnetic ordering.
